newsitem.title: UK: UK manufacturing expands for 13th month in June.
newsitem.headline: UK manufacturing expands for 13th month in June.

text.p: British manufacturing expanded for the 13th month in a row in June, the Chartered Institute of Purchasing and Supply (CIPS) said on Tuesday.
Its seasonally adjusted purchasing managers' index (PMI) dipped to 53.4 from 54.4 in May, but any reading above 50 signals an expansion in manufacturing.
"The main source of new business was the domestic market, with the strength of the pound again reported to have significantly subdued foreign demand," the CIPS said.
Export orders rose modestly due to the continued strengthening of economic growth in overseas markets and total order levels showed significant growth as a result.
The report, which is sponsored by Reuters, is considered to be a reliable barometer of the performance of manufacturing industry.

Purchasing managers reported further growth in output to meet the rise in order books. However, although more than a quarter of all firms raised production during the month, growth slowed compared to the level recorded in May and was the lowest level seen so far this year.
The deceleration was in part attributable to an increased incidence of firms deliberately reducing stocks of finished goods in order to cut costs.
The CIPS said companies had yet to experience significant capacity constraints or the potential inflationary impact on prices that tends to accompany supply shortages.
"Suppliers were reported to have had little difficulty in meeting existing levels of demand and one in five firms recorded a fall in prices compared with May," it said.
Manufacturers reported a further significant fall in input prices in June and average prices have now fallen for 20 consecutive months.
The strength of the pound was again the principal factor behind falling input prices.
Manufacturing firms remained reluctant to take on new staff in June and employment showed only modest growth.
